# Chemistry Year 9 Topic 1 - 2



## Topic 1 - States of matter

___
<br>

### Solids, liquids and gases


Matter is *anything* that *takes up space* and all matter is made up of *tiny particles that are constantly moving*. Chemistry is the *study of matter*.

When a solute *dissolves* into a solvent, the particles in the solute **break off and move** within the particles of the solvent.  

**1.	Solids**
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;*a.*	The particles in a solid are closely packed and in an ordered arrangement. They cannot move past each other. As a result, they have a fixed volume and shape, and cannot be compress *(when they are packed close enough to each other.)*

**2.	Liquids**
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;*a.*	The particles in a liquid are **closely packed** and are **disordered** as they **can move past each other**. As a result, they have a **fixed volume**, they **take the shape of their container** and **can flow but cannot be compressed** *(minimally.)*

**3.	Gases**
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;*a.*	Particles in a gas are **widely spaced** and **move randomly**. As a result, they have a **very low density**, **flow easily** and **fill their container** and **can be compressed**.

<br>

All solids are given *common properties* which are called the **properties of solids**. They have a **fixed volume** and **cannot be compressed**. They also have a **fixed shape** and **cannot be poured** because of the inability to flow. They also have a **higher density than other materials**.


Liquids also **cannot be compressed**. They have a **fixed volume**, but they **can flow** and **do not have a fixed shape**. This means that they **will always take the shape of their container**.

Gases can be **compressed** and have **no fixed shape**. They will **fill any container**. Gases are **less dense than liquids**, *which is why bubbles rise in a fizzy drink*.

<br>

### Brownian Motion

*Scottish* scientist **Robert Brown**, known for his *study of botany*, observed in 1938 that *pollen grains moved in a zig-zag manner while suspended in water under a microscope*, leading him to believe they *were alive and capable of movement*. Despite ruling out life in the experiment, he could not explain the motion. Nearly *eight years later* in 1983, Albert Einstein proposed a theory that **invisible water particles were bombarding the grains from all sides, collectively influencing their movement**.

<br>

### Diffusion

Diffusion happens when *particles become a gas and* **spread out**. Brownian motion plays a *big* part in diffusion. When a substance is warmer it *moves faster* **because it receives more energy**. When an object is lighter it moves faster **because it uses less energy**.

<br>

### State Changes

A substance changes state when it transforms from *one state of matter to another*.

$Solid$<sup>&nbsp;$-> Melting Point$</sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$Liquid$<sup>$-> Boiling Point$</sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;$Gas$
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<sup>&nbsp;$<- Freezing Point$</sup>&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;<sup>$<- Condensing point$</sup>

## Topic 2 - Separating Mixtures

___
<br>

### Key words:
**Residue** - An insoluble solid which remains on filter paper after, well, filtering

### Solution Mining

![A diagram of solution mining](data:image/png;base64,)
**Solution mining** works by *pumping water underground into a layer of rock salt* to dissolve the salt, then pumping the solution back out. The underground cavities formed by solution mining can make the ground unstable. A sinkhole is formed when the ground collapses into the cavity.

We can obtain pure salt from ***brine*** like this:
**1.	Dissolving the salt**
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;a.	This is explained earlier with the diagram.
**2.	Filtering the mixture**
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;a.	Get the filter funnel and place filter paper inside. Put it over the evaporating basin and pour the brine in the filter paper. Any remaining substances left on the filter paper is either undissolved salt or insoluble material.
**3.	Evaporating the filtrate**
&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;&nbsp;a.	Heat the basin with a Bunsen burner until crystals appear, then turn off the heat. Let the crystals form. Filter the mixture. Regular table salt can take a day or two to form.

> Brine is a mixture of salt and water, sometimes with a residue of salt, sand, clay, or other insoluble materials
